task.title: Looking at XML (for technical authors)
task.shortdesc: XML has its roots as a document markup language. Nevertheless, it's not pretty and you'll need an XML editor to ease your eyes from the angle brackets and to avoid typing closing element tags.

section.title: oXygen Author is a deservedly popular XML editor
section.p: Using an XML editor like oXygen can be unsettling for a technical author. There are many open windows displaying lots of technical options.
Nevertheless, I would resist using a Word-based tool or any other tools that purportedly makes the author's life easier.

At times, it's simpler to drop into the raw XML when the editor doesn't behave as expected, or it's just simpler. For example, editing file extensions in DITA maps is much easier using the Text view rather than the Author view.
The existing literature also assumes a solid IT support network.
Instead, it's worth considering oXygen as a nuclear-powered Word processor that can be used as a stand-alone application to get things done. It can produce web-sites and documents.

The one caveat is that, in order to conditionally-filter content, you're going to have to specialise the DITA open toolkit. This means edit a few lines in a text file, and create a new text file as well. It's not pleasant, but it's useful because you can them filter out content to suit. This can minimise the number of actual files you need to maintain.

DITA proponents will stress topicising into small topics, when in fact it makes managing things harder. Conditional text is one idea that DITA really gets right, becuase it reduces the number of files you'll ned to manage.

section.title: Getting oXygen Author
section.p: At the time of writing, oXygen is available on a cheap academic/personal license. The SyncRO Soft team are also happy to send a no-charge time-limited license. I've also found the Syncro Soft team very helpful in responding dorectliy to techincal queries.

Oxygen works with Windows and Ubuntu (I've tried both, and the license permits this.) and more. For some reason, I was able to install oXygen on a Windows work laptop without the usual administrator rights prompts.

There are two other versions of oXygen, but Author is the one to get for writing. It's got Author mode, comes integrated with the DITA-OT, and doesn't have too many unnecessary developer features that'll make you feel like a noob forever.

section.title: Use a programmer's text editor like Emacs for small edits and corrections
section.p: It's also useful to edit topic unrelated to the main project that you're working on, as the opened file won't get jumbled with your project files in oXygen.
